Introduction

YourCV is a system for generate and manage a large amount of CVs from a same set of datas. Let me explain. For example I was study journalism and worked in 7 mass-media (magazines, newspapers, radio and web-sites). At the same time I am a layouter and designed a large amount of books, newspapers and brochures. And I have worked in programming (Python, web-design, web-developing and so on). If I want to send my CV to a newspaper, the HR isn’t interested in my experience of programming or layouting. So I don’t need to include this informations about me in CV. Similar for case when I send a CV to web-desing company - my experience in journalism is not relevant in this case. For each case I need a different CV, but I don’t want to write a new CV each time when I need to send it. YourCV is a tool for selecting only needed datas from your biography and generate a new CV. You eaven don’t need to write this datas by yourself if you already introduce it in your Facebook account - just login, and the site will collect all informations itself.

udata.models.generate(p, id, lang, tex)

It’s a task for rqworker. Let see the options:

Parameters:
  • p (dict) – a dictionary of paths for texfile, generated pdf, storred pdf and storred png
  • id (int) – the id of CV. It used for remove the temporary files
  • lang (str) – the language for translate the CV template
  • tex (str or unicode) – the tex template

Todo

Because we move in direction of decentralised generation of pdf-s, we need to review the work of this function. The p dict will be not needed and the id will not be important. We need to return or a list of urls, or the resulted files

class udata.models.CVTemplate(*args, **kwargs)

Template for making CV

title = None

the title of template, must be a string

text = None

the template itself, must be a string

class udata.models.Human(*args, **kwargs)

General information about user

name = None

the name of user

birthday = None

his birthday (not used now)

phone = None

his phone number as string (any format)

email = None

his email (a valid email)

web = None

his website

user

the linked Django user for login

lang = None

the actual language, used for translate web-interface

prenume()

For some templates we need to separate name and surname. This method will get the surname

Returns:the surname of udata.models.Human
Return type:str
Example: 
>>> human = Human.objects.get(id=1)
>>> human.prenume()
u'Viorel'
nume()

Similar to udata.models.Human.prenume(), it’s get the name of human

Returns:the first name of udata.models.Human
Return type:str
Example: 
>>> human = Human.objects.get(id=1)
>>> human.nume()
u'Roman'
class udata.models.Study(*args, **kwargs)

What studies have user (like liceum, school, university etc.)

inst = None

The name of institution (Oxford University, ULIM, Stefan cel Mare Liceum

begin_year = None

The year when the studies began

end_year = None

The year when studies finished

human

The linked udata.models.Human

years()
Returns:a formated string of years diapason for be included in tex
Return type:str
class udata.models.Work(*args, **kwargs)

Work experience

inst = None

The name of employer (like Leg&Co SRL or Microsoft)

translations

The translations for position and some comments

begin_year = None

Year when the user start to work on this position

end_year = None

Year when he ends to work on this position

human

The linked udata.models.Human

years()

Similar to udata.models.Study.years()

class udata.models.Awards(*args, **kwargs)

Diploms, awards, courses etc.

translations

translations for title and description

Parameters:
  • title (str) – the name of award
  • description (text) – the description of award
year = None

The year when this award was gained

human

The linked udata.models.Human

class udata.models.Ability(*args, **kwargs)

Skills

translations

translated title and comments for skills.

Parameters:
  • title (str or unicode) – The name of skill (like Vectorial graphic or Text Processing)
  • comment (str or unicode) – The explanetion of skill (like Adobe Illustrator, Inkscape, good knowleges of MS Word etc.)
human

the linked udata.models.Human

class udata.models.CV(*args, **kwargs)

One of many sets of data, choised for create one CV

title = None

The title of generated CV. Usualy is used in the header of resulted pdf

human

The parent udata.models.Human

studies

The list of included udata.models.Study

works

The list of included udata.models.Work

abilities

The list of included udata.models.Ability

awards

The list of included udata.models.Awards

public = None

If the CV is generated successful - this value will be True

template

The template for generate pdf, more on udata.models.CVTemplate

mkurl(p)

Generate a url from absolute path to pdf or png

Parameters:p (str) – an absolute path to pdf or png
Returns:url
Return type:str
generate_tex(tpl, lang)

Generate a tex file from template in given language

Parameters:
  • tpl (str or unicode) – the django template for generating tex-file
  • lang (str or unicode) – the language for translate template
Returns:

the tex file
Return type:

str
generate_pdf()

This method generates the pdfs of cv in all languages.

In the begin we generate the tex file from template by calling self.generate_tex(tpl, lang), then we create the jobs using django_rq and call udata.models.generate() function.
